X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=7192225
X-Yahoo-Profile: ian_badcoe

Hi,
	(I've been on holiday so I'm a bit out of daye, this is from Kenneth's 
long discussion of about a week ago)

	Great analysis!  Just one small additional thought:  what do we mean by 
"dimensions" in the search space?

	Example, suppose we're doing some vision processing and by whatever means 
we arrive at a good solution.  Then we analyze the solution and we discover 
that, although it contains 1000 neurones, they are actually 10 copies(*) of 
the same 90-neurone structure (say an edge-detector) and a control network 
linking them together(**).  That's not really anything like as large a 
solution-space as it looked before the analysis, for two reasons:

(* or 10 "iso-neural" networks, e.g. not copies but functionally 
equivalent....)

(** current systems are unlikely to produce this, see below)

1) The 10 copies of the edge detector are 10 copies of the same set of 
dimensions, and thus a sub-space with 10-fold less dimensions than it 
originally appeared

2) The edge-detector and the control network are (arguably) not in the same 
search-space -- they are "orthogonal".  e.g. the modularity of the problem 
only requires them to respect the same "interface" connections, if does not 
required the edge-detector internal works to be finely tuned to match the 
control network.  Or, to put it another way, any functional edge detector 
would work with any functional control network.

	Stronger examples of modularity producing orthogonality can easily be 
dreamed up.  Consider the case of N sub-nets, each evolved to recognize a 
different input class, and a control net which just checks for which 
sub-net is reporting the highest confidence.  There is no dependency(***) 
between the sub-nets.  (Their internal dependencies are (i) report their 
confidence on a connection to the control net, (ii) the input data format.)

(*** dependency is the opposite of orthogonality)

	However, one cannot expect a homogeneous evolution procedure to just 
happen to produce orthogonal modules.  You need a modular evolution system:

	(slowest) mutate modularity
	(medium) try topologies within each module
	(fastest) play with the weights in each module

	- as people have begun to tinker with.

	Ian Badcoe
